Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Three-Color Photolithography for Scalable, Large-Area, Low-Cost Nanomanufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to create devices with finer features over larger areas is crucial to technological innovation in both mature and emerging industries. In the semiconductor industry, progress in increasing circuit density has been maintained by using light of ever shorter wavelengths to produce circuit patterns, but this method is expensive and further improvements are nearing their limit. This Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) project will use three beams of visible light of different wavelengths to produce nanoscale features with the improved resolution required to produce high density integrated circuits. Because visible light is inexpensive to produce, propagate and manipulate, the method promises to lower the cost of cutting-edge nanomanufacturing by a factor of 10 or more. The project team will collaborate with major industrial developers and end-users to transfer the technology to practice, providing a major boost to American competitiveness in scalable nanomanufacturing. The ever more compact and powerful devices that this technology will produce have the potential to impact virtually every imaginable aspect of technology and every member of our society.

The project team has researched and proven 2-color approaches to photolithography that have made possible the creation of high-resolution features using visible light. The basis of these techniques is that one color of light is used to initiate chemistry and a second color is used to inhibit it. However, these methods are not yet capable of producing the resolution needed to satisfy the requirements of the next node of the Semiconductor Roadmap. The stumbling block for 2-color approaches has been that initiation of chemistry competes with deactivation. The proposed 3-color approaches circumvent this problem. One color of light pre-activates chemistry, a second color of light deactivates the molecules, and a third color of light transforms pre-activated molecules into activated molecules that then undergo chemistry. This approach provides a viable path to attaining sub-20-nm resolution for scalable nanomanufacturing in 2 and 3 dimensions. The project team combines expertise in photolithography, photochemistry, spectroscopy and pattern transfer to realize this vision. The team will work closely with industrial collaborators who have expertise in commercial photoresists, photolithographic tool components and photolithographic simulation methods to ensure that the research methods and materials used are compatible with the needs and processes of the semiconductor industry and other consumer product industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scalable nanolithography refers to techniques though which patterns with features that are less than 1/1000th of the width of a human hair can be created reproducibly, over a large area, and with high yield. The continuous improvement in lithographic technologies over the past five decades have enabled integrated circuits, which are at the heart of digital devices, to have more and more features in the same area, and thereby to have ever greater capabilities. However, the next generation of commercial nanolithography, which is called extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography, is so complex and expensive that it is only ever likely to be used in extremely high-volume applications. Our interdisciplinary team has developed materials that enable an approach to scalable nanolithography that can be accomplished on a table top with inexpensive light sources. The approach, called 3-color lithography (3CL), could reduce the cost of creating cutting-edge integrated circuits by a factor of 10 to 100.

Intellectual merit: 3CL is an innovative new approach that relies on one color of light to prepare a chemical reaction to happen, a second color of light to reverse the effects of the first color in desired regions, and then a third color of light to start the chemical reaction in regions that were not exposed to the second color. A useful analogy is a gas burner. The first color of light is akin to starting the pilot light, the second color of light is akin to turning off the pilot light, and the third color of light is akin to turning on the gas. The difference is that in 3CL it is possible to control the spatial patterning of each of these three colors of light individually, and thereby can drive chemistry in an arbitrarily small region. Our team taken this method from concept to implementation, having developed two different classes of molecules that can undergo this type of process. Methods for making films of these materials that are less than 1/2000th as thick as a human hair, while still retaining the original chemical properties, have been developed. Films this thin are essential for the creation of nanoscale patterns. Exposure methods have been developed for these films, and materials have been created that show excellent performance in the next step of the lithographic process, which is known as pattern transfer. These accomplishments were made possible by the discovery of new types of light-initiated chemistry and the development of new experimental tools for understanding the molecular details of the chemistry of the materials.

Broader impacts: The materials and methods developed in this project are now ready to be tested for large-area creation of patterns, a necessary next step for transferring this technology to the semiconductor industry. At least two major companies are interested in supporting the next stage of this research. Ultimately, the ability to create integrated circuits with greater capabilities at a lower cost could have an impact on virtually every realm of our society, as this ability would allow for the creation of a new generation of consumer, medical, and industrial electronics. This project has also helped to promote the highly interdisciplinary training of the participants, whose work encompassed areas including chemistry, optics, plasma physics, materials science, and spectroscopy. The team members also worked closely with industry partners, and will be poised to be the leaders in the technology transfer of the discoveries made here.


Last Modified: 12/21/2019
Modified by: John T Fourkas
